prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from weakest flux in Nielbock & Schmidtobreick (2003) A&A 400 L5-L8. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from weakest flux in Nielbock & Schmidtobreick (2003) A&A 400 L5-L8. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. Best spatial resolution adopted to ensure best understanding of dust distribution. This will be smoothed to Band 6 resolution for colour maps. This allows observations in same configuration at same time, as targets are still expanding. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. Best spatial resolution adopted to ensure best understanding of dust distribution. This will be smoothed to Band 6 resolution for colour maps. This allows observations in same configuration at same time, as targets are still expanding. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. Best spatial resolution adopted to ensure best understanding of dust distribution. This will be smoothed to Band 6 resolution for colour maps. This allows observations in same configuration at same time, as targets are still expanding. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 10 beams to estimate peak - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. Best spatial resolution adopted to ensure best understanding of dust distribution. This will be smoothed to Band 6 resolution for colour maps. This allows observations in same configuration at same time, as targets are still expanding. LAS is an estimate, total extent of the objects will be larger than this

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 3 beams to estimate peak (the target i smore compact than other objects) - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply.

Source flux extrapolated via Raleigh-Jeans tail from IRAS. Total flux then assumed diluted over 3 beams to estimate peak (the object is more compact than the others) - but expect in practise to be clumped as seen in other objects, so concentration of flux likely greater than this would imply. Best spatial resolution adopted to ensure best understanding of dust distribution. This will be smoothed to Band 6 resolution for colour maps. This allows observations in same configuration at same time, as targets are still expanding.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Old nova remnants are the extended, dusty nebulae resulting from past classical nova outbursts. They typically eject 1/10000 solar mass of material over a few weeks at velocities of 400-4000 km/s. Many form optically thick dust while the central WD is still hot; others form optically thin dust. This proposal is aiming to image the cool dust in a sample of old classical novae to determine the distribution, temperature and mass, and so constrain dust formation and development theories in these objects. They are also applicable as environments for examining dust physics and chemistry in a wider context.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: ALMA observations of Luminous Red Novae M. Rushton Dust in Old Novae S. Eyres Dust in the old nova FH Ser S. Eyres A short-lived dusty nebula around the nova V1280 Sco O. Chesneau
